Download multiple Episodes from Multiple Seasons¶

WIll only pull a Signle Character dialog from previous notebook¶

Exercise to create a function download Southpark scripts from http://southparkwillie.com/, looking to pull all the episodes from all the seasons.

http://southparkwillie.com/Season1/E101script.htm http://southparkwillie.com/Season1/E102script.htm ... http://southparkwillie.com/Season2/E201script.htm http://southparkwillie.com/Season2/E202script.htm ... etc

Need to know the matrix of seasons and episodes Manually processed from http://southparkwillie.com/ScriptGuideIndex.htm
Seasons: 21
Episodes per Season: 10 - 18
-------------------- -------
Season Episodes
1: 13
2: 18
3: 17
4: 17
5: 14
6: 17
7: 15
8: 14
9: 14
10: 14
11: 14
12: 14
13: 14
14: 14
15: 14
16: 14
17: 10
18: 10
19: 10
20: 10
21: 10
In [1]:
#Loop through the Season's and Episodes and format the URL 
#http://southparkwillie.com/Season1/E101script.htm
season_episode_list = [13, 18, 17, 17, 14, 17, 15, 14, 14, 14, 14, 14, 14, 14, 14, 14, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10]
script_urls = []

for season in range(21):
    for episode in range(season_episode_list[season]):
        script_urls.append("http://southparkwillie.com/Season{0}/E{0}{1:0>2}script.htm".format(season + 1, episode + 1))
        
from pprint import pprint

pprint(script_urls)

In [2]:
#Create a function to cycle through the scripts and return a pandas dataframe with ALL the character/dialogue tables
import pandas as pd

def create_script_dataframe(script_urls):
    '''
    Function to create a pandas dataframe with two columns - "Character" / "Dialogue"
    script_urls - list of URLS
    
    return: pandas dataframe
    '''
    #Create a returnable Dataframe
    all_scripts_df = pd.DataFrame()
    
    #Loop through the URLs, grab the scripts and clean up
    for url in script_urls:
        script_list = pd.read_html(url)
        script_df = script_list[0]
        script = script_df.iloc[:,0:2]
        script = script.dropna()
        all_scripts_df = all_scripts_df.append(script, ignore_index = True)
        
    all_scripts_df.columns = ['Character', 'Dialogue']
    return all_scripts_df
        
df = create_script_dataframe(script_urls)

print(type(df))
print(df.head())
print(df.tail())
    

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
  Character                                           Dialogue
0     Boys:       School day, school day, teacher's golden ru
1     Kyle:  Ah, damn it! My little brother's trying to fol...
2      Ike:                                        Zeeponanner
3     Kyle:  Ike, you can't come to school with me. [Ike ch...
4  Cartman:                    Yeah, go home you little dildo.
             Character                                           Dialogue
77870  Officer Bright:                                     He broke free.
77871           Jimbo:               The President is on the loose again.
77872  Officer Bright:  He'll be even more desperatte now. It's goin' ...
77873            Stan:                      We can't destroy him, can we.
77874           Randy:    I don't know. I guess... it's up to the Whites.
In [3]:
#Get Character funtion from Exercise 1
import re

def get_character_dialogue(character, script):
    '''
       Retrieve the 'character' dialogue from the 'script'
       character: string
       script: pandas data frame
       
       Return: list of dialogue strings
    '''
    import re
    
    #TODO: Once more cleaning has been done on the Panda's side, this next line shoule not be required.
    character = character.title() + ":"
    
    #Initialize a list to return
    dialogue = []
    pattern = '\[.*?\]'
    
    for row_index in script.index.values:
        if script.loc[row_index, 'Character'] == character:
            dialogue.append(re.sub(pattern, '', script.loc[row_index, 'Dialogue']))
            
    return dialogue
In [4]:
#Test a character as we did in Exercise 1 - Cartman

cartman_dialogue = get_character_dialogue('cartman', df)

print(len(cartman_dialogue))
from pprint import pprint
pprint(cartman_dialogue)

10592

In [5]:
#Test a character as we did in Exercise 1 - Butters

butters_dialogue = get_character_dialogue('butters', df)

print(len(butters_dialogue))
from pprint import pprint
pprint(butters_dialogue)
